title: publish does not assure correct branch being checked out on remote

labels.name: severity-important
labels.description: major effect on the usability of a package, without rendering it completely unusable to everyone

body:
#### What is the problem?

Original issue #4347 reported by @soichih .  Decided to file a dedicated issue to "publish" aspect of it.
I found no prior issue in my [search](https://github.com/datalad/datalad/search?q=publish+not+master+branch&state=open&type=Issues)

Script to reproduce
```
D="$(mktemp -d --tmpdir dl-XXXXXXX)"
cd "$D"
# initial dataset without master
datalad create --no-annex origin && cd origin && git checkout -b other && touch 1 && datalad save 1
datalad create-sibling -s publish localhost:$D/publish
datalad publish --to publish

git -C $D/publish status
git -C $D/publish branch
/bin/ls -l $D/publish/1
```
produces
```
[INFO   ] Creating a new git repo at /home/yoh/.tmp/dl-Y92gok4/origin 
create(ok): /home/yoh/.tmp/dl-Y92gok4/origin (dataset)
Switched to a new branch 'other'
add(ok): 1 (file)
save(ok): . (dataset)
action summary:
  add (ok: 1)
  save (ok: 1)
[INFO   ] Connecting ... 
[INFO   ] Considering to create a target dataset /home/yoh/.tmp/dl-Y92gok4/origin at /home/yoh/.tmp/dl-Y92gok4/publish of localhost 
[INFO   ] Fetching updates for <Dataset path=/home/yoh/.tmp/dl-Y92gok4/origin> 
.: publish(?) [localhost:/home/yoh/.tmp/dl-Y92gok4/publish (git)]
[INFO   ] Adjusting remote git configuration 
[INFO   ] Running post-update hooks in all created siblings 
create_sibling(ok): . (dataset)
[INFO   ] Publishing <Dataset path=/home/yoh/.tmp/dl-Y92gok4/origin> to publish 
publish(ok): . (dataset) [pushed to publish: ['[new branch]']]                                                   
On branch master

No commits yet

nothing to commit (create/copy files and use "git add" to track)
  other
/bin/ls: cannot access '/home/yoh/.tmp/dl-Y92gok4/publish/1': No such file or directory
```

I am yet to countemplate possible side-effects (e.g. if local .git/config does remapping of references etc) but an obvious (re)solution could be for `publish` to assure that upon `push` of references remote has the correct branch checked out.
